stem: A compression injury to the radial nerve in the distal arm leads to which hallmark deficit pattern?

choices.A: Loss of elbow flexion and forearm supination
choices.B: Wrist drop with sensory loss over lateral dorsal hand
choices.C: Thenar eminence atrophy with loss of thumb opposition
choices.D: Isolated numbness of the medial palm and digit 5 only
choices.E: Weakness of finger ab-/adduction with preserved sensation

rationale_correct: Distal radial lesions classically cause wrist/digit extensor weakness (wrist drop) plus sensory loss over the lateral dorsum of the hand.

rationale_distractors.C: Thenar atrophy/opposition loss suggests median nerve injury.
rationale_distractors.D: Medial palm/digit 5 numbness points to ulnar distribution.
rationale_distractors.E: Interossei weakness (ab-/adduction) is ulnar and often includes sensory changes unless a pure motor branch lesion.

evidence.citation: Selski D. Nerve Injuries of the Upper Limb (Slides). 2022.
